bibl.title: [Letter] 1818 Jan. 28, Plainfield [North Carolina] [to] Ja[me]s M.[oore] King, Murfreesborough, Rutherford County, Tennessee / Ann Eliza King
bibl.author: King, Ann Eliza
bibl.note: Letter dated January 28, 1818 from Ann Eliza King to her Cousin James Moore King. The brief letter expresses her disappointment in not receiving a reply from her last letter, and her happiness to see him in the future.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

opener.add:
Letter to Jas M. King from Ann Eliza King
Jan 28 1818
Ann Eliza
DeVane and and Wm R are brother & sister

div1.p: I expected are this to have herd from you I am sorry that your correspondent is of so little value that you fail to answer the first letter. I should not have troubled you with a second, but from a consciousness of not being treated with that respect and friendship which is due to your Cousin, I could not forlorne to complain, I immagine from your long stay that you have depended more on your own choise than you could on mine, which was very write , my only request is that you will fetch the lovely unknown with you when you come. I should be extremely glad to form an acquaintance with one whome I immagine (as she is your choise) is all perfection
we are all in the land of the living Brother Wm has just (Wm R. King?) returned from Brother ⁁ John Devane Died Young & Mother are in a low state of health the rest of us are well.
